creator: bburdulis
title: Drawing Custom Toolpaths For CNC Milling (To Create Your Own Surfaces)
description: This project guides you through the process of drawing custom toolpaths for CNC milling to create unique surfaces, patterns, reliefs, and textures, offering more control than traditional CAM software.
steps: Build a 3D model of the surface or object using CAD software such as Inventor or Fusion 360.

Draw a 2D pattern that will serve as your toolpath, using techniques like dimensionally-constrained lines, parametric software, curve tweening, or vectorizing a hand-drawn pattern. Consider the stepover distance for relief depth and machining time.

Position the 2D pattern in relation to the 3D model, ensuring correct alignment, especially when importing from other software. Extend lines beyond the model's edge to ensure the tool clears on each pass.

Choose an endmill that will produce the desired surface finish (e.g., flat for stepped terraces, ball-nose for rounded grooves, V-groove for triangular facets). Also, consider the appropriate endmill diameter for the scale of your piece.

Use CAM software to create a toolpath from the 2D pattern, utilizing functions like "Project" (Fusion 360) or "Curve Machining" (Rhinoceros 3D). Input endmill information, select the 2D pattern lines, and choose the 3D model as the surface to be machined.  Consider a roughing operation or multiple step-downs depending on the material.

Simulate the toolpath in your CAM software to preview the combined result of the 2D toolpath, 3D model, and endmill. Check for collisions or overly aggressive passes, making necessary changes and simulating again.
Machine your custom toolpath after being satisfied with the simulation. Expect unexpected results and compare the machined object with the 3D model.
Analyze the machined result, reflecting on what works well and what doesn't to improve subsequent iterations.

creator: bburdulis
title: Drawing Custom Toolpaths For CNC Milling (To Create Your Own Surfaces)
description: This project describes how to draw custom toolpaths for CNC milling to create unique patterns, reliefs, textures, and complex surfaces, offering more control than automatically generated toolpaths.
steps: Build a 3D model of the surface or object using CAD software like Inventor or Fusion 360. Start with a simple form to easily study the effect of the resulting pattern.

Draw a 2D pattern that will serve as the toolpath. Techniques include drawing a dimensionally-constrained system of lines in Fusion 360, using parametric software, or scanning a hand-drawn pattern and converting it into vectors. The distance between lines is the stepover.

Position the 2D pattern in relation to the 3D model, ensuring correct alignment. The pattern can 'float' above or below the model. Extend the lines of the projected toolpath slightly beyond the edge of the model.
Choose the appropriate endmill, considering the desired surface finish (e.g., flat endmill for stepped terraces, ball-nose endmill for rounded grooves) and the scale of the piece.

Create a toolpath from the 2D pattern using the 'Project' function in Fusion 360 or 'Curve Machining' in Rhinoceros3D. Input endmill information, select the 2D pattern lines, and select the 3D model as the surface to be machined.
Run a simulation in the CAM software to preview the combined result of the custom 2D toolpath, 3D model, and chosen endmill. Check for collisions or overly-aggressive passes.
Machine the custom toolpath once satisfied with the simulation. Be prepared for unexpected results due to the translation from a 3D visualization to a physical material.
Analyze the machined object, reflect on what works well and what does not, and iterate to improve the design and machining process.
